comments.commentBody:
I've spent a lot of time looking in to all of these online rental/retail sites, and I must say my favorite of the bunch is Luxemi.com. The sense of style with them seems really chic and like one I could trust. They also let people do new retail or rental which I appreciated.

I ordered from them twice and used them for my wedding guests and everyone had a great experience...it will be interesting to see who else enters this space!

Government of India imposed FDI bill haphazardly,Not consulting allies their own members..What in intention of government to place this bill hurried that is also puzzling.Shamefully  they.  withdraw that also  beyond  understandable.In recent history government of India fumbling too much taking decision.No one is there who can lead the nation so India is governing just like functional anarchy.

All that Sibal says is not to shutter up the internet but to use a filter so that sexy trash, abusive invectives/ exchanges, and terrorist propaganda do not corrupt impressionable young minds. I see nothing wrong in that.

Veevip Sarathy

Without trying to sound supportive or critical of the opinion reflected in this blog, I wanted to point out that the author is trying to point out a mindset (the  italics words reflect a mindset). He is not trying to generalize or categorize India or Indians.  Without supporting or opposing the author's views, as an Indian, we should at least be able to acknowledge that the mindset defined here is to a great extent true. I also found the article link posted by Gaurav (from TX) very useful in understanding this blog.

Heart warming (pun intended) to see that once again, we are harming the environment indirectly by exporting our lead to Mexico. We live in a great place here where big business puts monetary gain over the air we all breathe. Domestic  battery company's shipping out  waste batteries to other countries just to buy them back due to the fact that, it COSTS LESS is a high environmental injustice. The batteries harvested for lead in other countries harm people and add particulate matter into the air. In addition, what is happening to all of the acid that mexico tosses? does it... go to LaLa land?NO. Finally shipping the battery's to and fro the manufacturer add more carbon emissions to the environment than just dealing with battery's domestically. Then again, this could just be of the many problems in our world that is too tough to solve, people are bent on making money; the force that drives our world.

Only when citizens back the efforts of the ACs that are working on these problems. The only reason why things get reformed in the US is that people ' volunteer ' to help the non profits to achieve the common goal, something [ altruistas ] that is still very immature in Mexico

Shame on all the people involved in this shady business in both countries. We are not only "the backyard" of the USA, but also their city dump. This is one more sad story of our relation with some americans that see us these way. Thank God there are also all the enviroment groups both sides of the border that no doubt will take inmediate action to solve this terrible situation. I hope.

USA needs the illegal drugs.  USA sells Mexico guns and encourages the blood spilling to make sure the drugs keep coming across the border. USA is the great junkie nation which will stop at nothing to get the drugs.

Enough with blaming America for this. This is Mexico's problem. Mexico has a government (last time I checked) that unfortunately has contempt for its own people. Mexico also has some of the richest businessmen in the world who could throw some money at this problem to help fix it. Let's start with Carlos Slim, with his warchest of $74 billion.
Great reply, the sad part is most people will not get it.

The Mexican government is one of those that approach the republicans small government ideal. A very weak government, a humongous disparity in wealth, no laws or regulations that are enforced. Basically, republican paradise. We are next, so get used to it.

Just as "spent" televisions are shipped to China to pollute the land, air and water "over there," we are learning that America uses the rest of the world as "it's toxic dump site."

Just to let everyone know: "Out of sight and out of mind does not work."
The earth's different ecosystems always find a way to interact with each other. So basically, this means that eventually "what goes around comes around, and vice versa.

You would have to be nieve to think that what the US is doing is okay. It is not!!

Just think if the republicans win in 2012 we can resume processing the batteries here as we will be getting rid of the EPA and all those pesky environmental regulations. Imagine all the jobs we will create!!

With all due respect, Al, this sort of black and white thinking is unhelpful. Yes, it is all *your* fault that Mexican citizens have been poisoned by lead. Sure. Our dirty business practices are mostly to blame. The trouble is that chemicals have wanderlust. Whatever is put into any nation's environment will inevitably go elsewhere via rain, streams running into the ocean, other products shipped/brought here, etc.,  The interconnections make it difficult to place the blame squarely on a single set of shoulders. That said, if we want to call ourselves a first world nation, don't we have a responsibility to ourselves and others to act ethically? If we're so exceptional, we should be an example.

Really? Mexico is run by a financial elite that represents less than 10% of the population. They do not care what happens to the ordinary people in their country. Sound familiar? Want to bet whether the companies doing the battery work in Mexico are owned by US corporations who weren't about spend the money to do a quality job in the US?
And where did those billions of dollars come from?  The US taxpayer - not the corporations doing the polluting. How nice.

We have been down this road before.  What this article doesn't mention is that US gave Mexico billions of dollars to clean up Mexico's toxic waste sites that Mexico blamed on US.  Mexico was then supposed to implement pollution standards.  The logic was that this money benefited both countries.  That happened in then 1990s.   The US sent the money.  Why didn't Mexico keep their committment?

It is disgusting that companies would opt to meet lower safety standards knowing that their practices harm children and adults. Never mind that another locale doesn't require practices that lessen risk of illness; the human ability to feel for another being ought to guide executives to demand and ensure that best known practices be followed. Never mind the tedious meetings and contract negotiations and middle management and ignorance of some that lead businesses to do much harm; those with a moral compass and a practiced analytic ability to understand science need to insist when the alternative becomes the stealing of others' children's rights to thrive as developmentally healthy as possible.

It doesn't matter.  Mexico is saddled by NAFTA.  Also, as I've learned from listening to Democracy Now's live coverage of the Durban S.A climate talks (not barley mentioned by the likes of NYT, CNN, etc) the rest of the world's accepted that the USA won't abide by the Kyoto emissions deadlines.  However if the rest of the world wants to enact policies to reduce their carbon emmissions the US steps right in with either sanctions or bribes thereby assuring that the rest of the world pollutes the the same levels as we do.  It's horrible and it's corrupt.

So, when the debate is about how "over regulation" by the government inhibits business growth, is this the type of Dickens-like scenario envisioned by the GOP? Clearly the lax rules that are on the books in Mexico are ignored, enabling commerce and market driven demand to run its course. I'm sure many GOP candidates would scoff that such a result could happen here. But based on strict and pure Friedman free market principles endorsed and trumpeted by the economic right, what would be the firewall against such a result? If not good will and common environmental sense (an anathema to true practitioners) then what? Good governmental regulation, as practiced here. As far as "Jacks" comment, which could be taken as "tongue in cheek", not all jobs are jobs that should be done.
It might be, but the article said "smuggling" not merely importing.
So much for the progress of Obama's green policies.

Yes, but first the people who can do something about it have to be informed through their professional associations and 'volunteer' time as altruistas to sustainability non profits. Then the less fortunate need to be educated to use the Internet but through Bibliotecas Digitales like the ones we are proposining to be set up on MX. We have received zero support from any Mexican. Replies to emails from professionals after the first one are non existent. Oja a ojo is a thing of the past. That reform to the culture will take lots of effort.

As an engineer, I wonder if we in Mexico can develop a parallel clean technology as that in the US. I feel that it is just a matter of working on that: so many companies work in Mexico under USA standards.

So, having clean processes in Mexico is not impossible, but we citizens must demand the contribution and regulation from our government.

And still taht will be a good business for the people involved.

The comments demonstrate that even people who read the NYTimes aren't necessarily informed.

"Why doesn't Mexico protect its people?" Because they'd have to fund police, inspectors, scientists. And they can't afford to. And when the Republicans get elected here they'll go after the EPA too, and cut taxes and eliminate the regulartions that keep this stuff from happening here. . We might be headed down the same road.

The US has helped undermine Mexico's economy -- its agriculture, its manufacturing. (See: effects of globalization, esp. NAFTA.) Wealthy Mexicans are living the life our 1 percent want-- they live in mansions behind walls, and send their kids abroad to school. They dont' care how the poor live in the slums or the hinterlands.

"It has long been known within the scientific community that the battery in a hybrid vehicle (e.g. Toyota Prius) is much worse for the environment/planet long-term then a non-hybrid vehicle."

Nonsense. Most hybrids use nickel metal hydride batteries which are less toxic than the lead-acid batteries in most cars. Lithium ion batteries are another battery type that car makers are interested in using. They're lighter and less toxic than nickel-metal hydride batteries. In addition, car manufacturers offer recycling programs for the battery packs in their hybrids.

Ironic that this article is appearing during the Christmas--over-consumption of non-essential goods by Americans desperate to believe the economy will improve season. Buy more. Pollute more. It goes hand in hand

i'm quite certain that many of the unemployed in this country would welcome the opportunity to have this process performed in the u.s. so many people out of work here that it's no longer possible to pick what job you don't want. it's very reasonable to assume that safe working practices would take place if the processors were recognizable to the industry.
Well, then, you can depend on the selflessness of the corporations involved to find those countries least able to protect themselves and their people.
